00002 #include <string.h>

00005 SKError::SKError(int error, const char* errorMessage)
00006     : fError(error)
00007 {
00008     InitErrorMessage(errorMessage);
00009     if (DO_DEBUG)
00010         printf("SKError: %s\n", errorMessage);  
00011 }
00012 
00013 // Initializes the error message; errorMessage is 
00014 // assumed to be non-null
00015 void SKError::InitErrorMessage(const char* errorMessage)
00016 {
00017     int len = strlen(errorMessage);
00018     fErrorMessage = new char[len + 1];
00019         // TODO: We need to do something intelligent here if
00020         // the allocation fails, possibly have a static
00021         // "Insufficent Memory" exception (not derived from
00022         // SKError) that we could throw.
00023     strcpy( fErrorMessage, errorMessage );
00024 }
00025 
00026 SKError::~SKError()
00027 {
00028     delete fErrorMessage;
00029 }
00030 
00031 const int SKError::Error() const
00032 {
00033     return fError;
00034 }
00035 
00036 const char* SKError::ErrorMessage() const
00037 {
00038     return fErrorMessage;
00039 }
